channel.title: NYT > Business
channel.copyright: Copyright 2025 The New York Times Company

item.title: Does China Have a Robot Bubble?
item.description: The Chinese government is betting that robots will drive economic growth. But the bots can’t really do much yet.
item.dc:creator: Meaghan Tobin and Xinyun Wu
item.media:description: A new Chinese humanoid robot appeared so lifelike that workers cut its leg open during a demonstration last month.

item.title: On British Roads, Chinese Cars Are Racing Ahead
item.description: BYD, Chery and other Chinese automakers are winning over drivers in Britain, where tariffs are low and buyers are open to new brands.
item.dc:creator: Eshe Nelson
item.media:credit: Owen Richards for The New York Times

item.title: Jared Kushner’s Affinity Partners Pulls Out of Bid for Warner Bros. Discovery
item.description: Affinity Partners, Mr. Kushner’s private equity firm, played a small financial role in Paramount’s $108 billion offer, but it had attracted political attention to the deal.
item.dc:creator: Lauren Hirsch
item.media:credit: Haiyun Jiang for The New York Times
item.media:description: Jared Kushner, President Trump’s son-in-law, founded his investment firm, Affinity Partners, shortly after the end of Mr. Trump’s first term.

item.title: U.S. Threatens Penalties Against European Tech Firms Amid Regulatory Fight
item.description: The Trump administration singled out European tech firms by name and promised economic consequences Tuesday unless the E.U. rolls back tech regulation and lawsuits.
item.dc:creator: Ana Swanson, Adam Satariano and Jeanna Smialek
item.category: Office of the United States Trade Representative
item.media:description: The Office of the United States Trade Representative, led by Jamieson Greer, said that the European Union had “persisted in a continuing course of discriminatory and harassing lawsuits, taxes, fines, and directives” against U.S. companies.

item.title: White House Dismisses Rise in Unemployment
item.description: The Trump administration looked to recast elements of a dour jobs report Tuesday as a sign of strength.
item.dc:creator: Tony Romm
item.category: White House Council of Economic Advisers
item.media:description: The White House insisted on Tuesday that the economy remained strong under President Trump’s watch.

item.title: What to know about the report.
item.dc:creator: Rebecca Davis O’Brien

item.title: New York Accuses UPS of Seasonal Worker Wage Theft
item.description: In a lawsuit, the state’s attorney general, Letitia James, said UPS had “repeatedly and persistently” failed to pay seasonal workers for all of the time they spent on the job.
item.dc:creator: Amanda Holpuch
item.media:description: Representatives of Teamsters Local 804 appeared this week at a news conference with Letitia James, New York’s attorney general. They said seasonal UPS workers were not being fully paid for their time on the job.

item.title: Europe May Roll Back Combustion Engine Ban
item.description: A proposal to revise an E.U. law requiring carmakers to stop producing combustion engines by 2035 would offer some relief to automakers, but it sets back the region’s climate goals.
item.dc:creator: Patricia Cohen and Eshe Nelson
item.media:credit: Laetitia Vancon for The New York Times
item.media:description: Electric vehicles at a BMW factory in Munich. Premier automakers like BMW will benefit if an emission ban in Europe is rolled back.

item.title: Netflix Adds Podcasts in Deal With iHeartMedia
item.description: The streaming service now has about 30 video podcasts lined up for 2026, including the influential radio show “The Breakfast Club.”
item.dc:creator: Jessica Testa
item.media:credit: Aleksey Kondratyev for The New York Times
item.media:description: Netflix said it planned to feature more podcasts, calling the shows from iHeartMedia an “initial collection.”

item.title: Why a Data Deluge Is Unlikely to Settle the Rates Debate
item.description: A backlog of government economic data is set to ease, but disagreement on the country’s economic outlook could linger.
item.dc:creator: Andrew Ross Sorkin, Bernhard Warner, Sarah Kessler, Michael J. de la Merced, Niko Gallogly and Brian O’Keefe
item.media:description: In an unusual move, the Bureau of Labor Statistics is expected to publish jobs data today from October and November — but key details will be missing.

item.title: Jobs Data Is Finally Back. But the Economic Picture Is Still Blurry.
item.description: November’s job report may be distorted as a result of the government shutdown, limiting how much it will influence the Federal Reserve’s next interest rate decision in January.
item.dc:creator: Ben Casselman and Colby Smith
item.media:credit: Caroline Gutman for The New York Times
item.media:description: Jerome H. Powell, the Federal Reserve chair, warned last week that policymakers would have to take the November data lightly.

item.title: Senators Investigate Role of A.I. Data Centers in Rising Electricity Costs
item.description: Three Democrats are seeking information from tech firms about the growing energy use of data centers and the utility bills of individuals and other businesses.
item.dc:creator: Ivan Penn and Karen Weise
item.media:credit: Nathan Howard for The New York Times
item.media:description: The energy needs of data centers used for artificial intelligence are forcing utility companies to spend billions of dollars to upgrade the power grid, the lawmakers said.

item.title: Jobs Report Could Provide Overdue Clarity on Uncertain Economy
item.description: Employers added 64,000 jobs in November, according to data delayed by the government shutdown, but the unemployment rate rose to a four-year high of 4.6 percent.
item.dc:creator: Rebecca Davis O’Brien

item.title: The View From My Seat at an Ultraluxurious Dinner
item.description: A reporter traveled to Las Vegas to learn how one of the world’s most over-the-top dining experiences comes together.
item.dc:creator: Calum Marsh
item.media:credit: Roger Kisby for The New York Times
item.media:description: A fine dining pop-up in Las Vegas was built directly atop the Bellagio hotel’s man-made lake.

item.title: Volkswagen to End Production at German Plant, a First in Company History
item.description: The auto giant stopped making cars at the plant in Dresden, which opened in 2001, as it faces weaker demand and steep U.S. tariffs.
item.dc:creator: Gregory Schmidt
item.media:description: Volkswagen’s site in Dresden, known as the “Transparent Factory,” will be converted to a technology research hub.

item.title: Trump Files $10 Billion Suit Over BBC Documentary
item.description: The British broadcaster, which has expressed regret over the editing of video clips about the president, has rejected claims that the error was evidence of a fundamental bias in its news reporting.
item.dc:creator: Michael D. Shear
item.media:description: The BBC’s board chairman apologized in a letter to a British parliamentary committee, saying the documentary’s editing had been an “error of judgment.”

item.title: Robert Samuelson, Award-Winning Economics Columnist, Dies at 79
item.description: He was a familiar byline in Newsweek and The Washington Post for decades, explaining the intricacies of economic policy in reader-friendly vernacular.
item.dc:creator: Michael S. Rosenwald
item.media:credit: Sarah L. Voisin/The Washington Post, via Getty Images
item.media:description: Mr. Samuelson in 2019. “He would constantly puncture liberal shibboleths,” a former colleague said. “But he could go after the other side, too, and he had the goods.”

item.title: Ford Will Take $19.5 Billion Hit as It Rolls Back E.V. Plans
item.description: Ford Motor said the costs came from its decision to make fewer electric vehicles than it had planned and more hybrids that use both gasoline engines and batteries.
item.dc:creator: Jack Ewing
item.media:credit: Brittany Greeson for The New York Times
item.media:description: A Ford F-150 Lightning electric truck at the company’s plant in Dearborn, Mich., in 2022. The Lightning will no longer be a pure electric vehicle.

item.title: Brian McGrory Returns to Boston Globe as Top Editor After 2023 Exit
item.description: Brian McGrory led the news organization for a decade until he departed in early 2023.
item.dc:creator: Katie Robertson
item.media:description: Brian McGrory, center, in 2014, when The Boston Globe was awarded a Pulitzer Prize for its coverage of the 2013 Boston Marathon bombing.

item.title: SpaceX’s Next Big Launch Could Be an I.P.O.
item.description: Elon Musk’s rocket and satellite giant is already planning a stock sale at an $800 billion valuation. Going public could put it in the trillion-dollar club.
item.dc:creator: Andrew Ross Sorkin, Bernhard Warner, Sarah Kessler, Michael J. de la Merced, Niko Gallogly, Brian O’Keefe, Ian Mount and Vivienne Walt
item.media:credit: Meridith Kohut for The New York Times
item.media:description: SpaceX is set to be valued at $800 billion — and potentially a lot more if it goes public.

item.title: Roomba Maker iRobot Files for Bankruptcy, With Chinese Supplier Taking Control
item.description: Founded in 1990 by three M.I.T. researchers, iRobot introduced its vacuum in 2002. Its restructuring will turn the company over to its largest creditor.
item.dc:creator: Meaghan Tobin and Xinyun Wu
item.media:description: Roomba vacuums on display in California last year. The chief executive of iRobot said the company’s acquisition by its Chinese supplier would secure its “long-term future.”

item.title: 5 Hotels for the Holidays
item.description: From Colorado Springs to Vienna, here’s where you can indulge in a festive winter break.
item.dc:creator: Stephanie Rosenbloom

item.title: Trump’s Cuts Hobbled US Labor Board, Leaving Festering Disputes and a Power Struggle
item.description: Advocates fear damage to labor protections if the Supreme Court upholds the president’s move to control federal agency staffing.
item.dc:creator: Rebecca Davis O’Brien
item.media:description: The Washington headquarters of the National Labor Relations Board, which is down to a single member. In the interim, California and New York want to strengthen their boards.

item.title: How to Avoid an Airbnb Fail
item.description: Sometimes, a short-term rental doesn’t live up to its billing. Here’s how to recognize red flags before you turn up at the front door.
item.dc:creator: Adrienne Wichard-Edds

item.title: As Regional Theaters Struggle, Some Defy the Odds
item.description: Naples, Fla., and Milwaukee are quite different, but have one thing in common: They are home to regional theaters that are thriving.
item.dc:creator: Michael Paulson
item.media:credit: Scott McIntyre for The New York Times
item.media:description: Gulfshore Playhouse in Naples, Fla., is now presenting productions in its new main stage theater with 400 seats, twice the size of its former home.

item.title: China Approaches First Investment Decline in 3 Decades
item.description: A broad measure of investment fell more than 10 percent in November, continuing a recent reversal and signaling the depth of China’s property crisis.
item.dc:creator: Daisuke Wakabayashi
item.media:description: A residential complex being built by Vanke in Nanjing, China. Vanke is the latest developer in financial distress as property investment has plunged.

item.title: The S.E.C. Was Tough on Crypto. It Pulled Back After Trump Returned to Office.
item.description: An investigation by The Times found the administration’s change in enforcement benefited the industry, including companies that had ties to the president.
item.dc:creator: Ben Protess, Andrea Fuller, Sharon LaFraniere, Seamus Hughes and Elena Shao

item.title: Rodney Brooks, the Godfather of Modern Robotics, Says the Field Has Lost Its Way
item.description: Rodney Brooks, famous for the Roomba, argues the humanoid robot craze in Silicon Valley is doomed to fail.
item.dc:creator: Tim Fernholz
item.media:credit: Aaron Wojack for The New York Times

item.title: Flight Returns to Dulles After Engine Failure During Takeoff, F.A.A. Says
item.description: United Airlines Flight 803, which was headed to Tokyo, safely landed at Washington Dulles International Airport on Saturday, officials said.
item.dc:creator: Mark Walker and Aimee Ortiz
item.media:description: Smoke from a fire near Washington Dulles International Airport on Saturday.

item.title: U.S.-U.K. Trade Deal Hits Stumbling Block
item.description: The U.S. government has paused a tech-focused trade pledge with Britain over broader disagreements about Britain’s digital regulations and food safety rules.
item.dc:creator: Eshe Nelson and Ana Swanson
item.media:description: President Trump and Prime Minister Keir Starmer of Britain in September, after signing an agreement that pledged to extend research collaborations and deepen partnerships in the tech industry.

item.title: My Boss Got Way Too Drunk at the Christmas Party
item.description: And now I’m dealing with the consequences.
item.dc:creator: Max Read
item.media:credit: Photo illustration by Margeaux Walter for The New York Times

item.title: Social Security Disability, a Financial Protection for Some Workers, Is at a Crossroads
item.description: The benefits provide important economic support for older people who cannot work. The White House recently halted changes to the program that had worried some experts.
item.dc:creator: Mark Miller

item.title: Elon Musk’s SpaceX Valued at $800 Billion, as It Prepares to Go Public
item.description: A sale of insider shares at $421 a share would make Mr. Musk’s rocket company the most valuable private company in the world, as it readies for a possible initial public offering next year.
item.dc:creator: Ryan Mac
item.media:credit: Meridith Kohut for The New York Times
item.media:description: The SpaceX launchpad in South Texas in June 2024. The company said in a letter to employees on Friday that it could go public in 2026.

item.title: F.D.A. Approves Two New Drugs to Treat Gonorrhea
item.description: The sexually transmitted disease has become increasingly resistant to existing antibiotics.
item.dc:creator: Andrew Jacobs
item.media:description: Neisseria gonorrhoeae, the bacterium that causes gonorrhea.

item.title: Canadians Rush to Buy Stockpiles of Boycotted U.S. Liquor
item.description: Four Canadian provinces are selling off the American liquor they pulled from shelves in protest over President Trump’s tariffs. Some bourbon drinkers are thrilled.
item.dc:creator: Michael Levenson
item.media:description: American alcohol products were removed from store shelves in much of Canada when U.S. tariffs against the country went into effect in March.

item.title: Arthur L. Carter, 93, Dies; Investment Banker Founded a Cheeky Newspaper
item.description: After making a fortune on Wall Street, he bought The Nation magazine and founded The New York Observer, which one writer called a “maypole of Manhattan gossip and intrigue.”
item.dc:creator: Sam Roberts
item.media:description: Arthur L. Carter in the offices of The New York Observer, in 1987, the year he founded it. “The vocabulary of contemporary journalism, saturated with gimlet-eyed social observation and a catty mistrust of convention, owes much to The Observer,” the media critic David Carr wrote.

item.title: Businesses Are Cashing In on Trump’s Tax Cuts
item.description: Corporate tax revenue has quickly dipped since Republicans passed tax cuts this summer. But economists think these tax breaks might be worth it.
item.dc:creator: Andrew Duehren
item.media:credit: Dave Sanders for The New York Times
item.media:description: While Americans won’t begin to see tax savings until next year, some corporations, including Walmart, are already reporting reductions to their tax payments in 2025.

item.title: Cooling Labor Market and Elevated Inflation Stoke Fed Divisions on Rate Cuts
item.description: Fed officials explained their opposition to the central bank’s decision this week to cut interest rates by a quarter of a percentage point.
item.dc:creator: Colby Smith
item.media:credit: Caroline Gutman for The New York Times
item.media:description: The divisions on the Federal Reserve have forced Jerome H. Powell, the Fed chair, to navigate the difficult task of trying to reach a consensus among his colleagues.

item.title: A Seized Oil Tanker Off Venezuela and the Big Business of Dark Fleet Smuggling
item.description: The U.S. seizure of a vessel off Venezuela is likely to squeeze the country’s government, but do little to counter the tankers that secretively move oil from sanctioned countries.
item.dc:creator: Rebecca F. Elliott and Peter Eavis
item.media:credit: Adriana Loureiro Fernandez for The New York Times
item.media:description: Oil tankers anchored at a refinery in Punto Fijo, Venezuela, in 2022. The country relies heavily on a so-called dark fleet to export its oil.

item.title: Russia Sues Holder of Frozen Assets Europe Wants for Ukraine Loan
item.description: The lawsuit was a warning to European officials who are racing to agree to a plan to use Russian government assets in Europe to lend money to Ukraine.
item.dc:creator: Paul Sonne and Jeanna Smialek
item.media:description: The headquarters of the Euroclear depository in Brussels. Russia’s Central Bank said it had filed a lawsuit in Moscow against the depository.

item.title: Elon Musk Tests Europe’s Willingness to Enforce Its Online Laws
item.description: Backed by White House officials, the tech billionaire has lashed out at the European Union after his social media platform X was fined last week.
item.dc:creator: Adam Satariano and Kate Conger
item.media:description: Elon Musk has grown increasingly confrontational toward Europe over the past year.

item.title: Should You Donate to Charity This Year or Wait? It Depends.
item.description: Changes in the tax law will have different effects on people who take the standard deduction versus high earners who itemize.
item.dc:creator: Ann Carrns

item.title: Questions About Larry Ellison’s Financing Pledge for Paramount’s Bid for Warner Bros.
item.description: The Oracle co-founder has pledged billions to finance Paramount’s takeover bid for Warner Bros. Discovery — which has questions about his commitment.
item.dc:creator: Andrew Ross Sorkin, Bernhard Warner, Sarah Kessler, Michael J. de la Merced, Niko Gallogly, Brian O’Keefe, Lauren Hirsch and Ian Mount
item.media:description: Larry Ellison is one of the world’s richest men. But the details behind his financial commitment to Paramount’s takeover bid for Warner Bros. Discovery was a concern for the target company’s board.

item.title: Historic Shift Underway in China’s Economy as Investment Slump Deepens
item.description: Investment in manufacturing, infrastructure and property is expected to fall this year, a remarkable turn for an economy whose growth reshaped the world.
item.dc:creator: Daisuke Wakabayashi and Amy Chang Chien
item.media:credit: Qilai Shen for The New York Times
item.media:description: An auto factory in Ningbo, China. The Chinese government has discouraged manufacturers of electric vehicles from engaging in ruthless competition.

item.title: Paramount Says Money Is No Object. Warner Bros. Isn’t Convinced.
item.description: Larry Ellison is backstopping Paramount’s bid for Warner Brothers, but Warner Brothers is concerned that the billionaire has not provided a personal guarantee to pay.
item.dc:creator: Lauren Hirsch
item.media:description: Larry Ellison, who co-founded the software group Oracle, is worth around $273 billion.

item.title: Tech Support Scammers Stole $85,000 From Him. His Bank Refused a Refund.
item.description: A retired lawyer lost the money in a tech support scam, a type of online fraud that is surging. Citibank said it couldn’t recover the funds, which criminals wired from inside his account.
item.dc:creator: Tara Siegel Bernard
item.media:credit: Victor J. Blue for The New York Times
item.media:description: David Welles, 87, was ensnared in a tech support scam that allowed fraudsters to take over his personal devices with remote access software. They made a wire transfer of $85,000 from his bank account.

item.title: The Fine Art of Managing Christie’s
item.description: As more people tune in for the “theater” of high-end auctions, Bonnie Brennan is trying to convert them into clients.
item.dc:creator: Jordyn Holman
item.media:credit: George Etheredge for The New York Times; Chagall painting © 2025 Artists Rights Society (ARS), New York, via ADAGP, Paris
item.media:description: Bonnie Brennan joined Christie’s in 2012, after a 15-year stint at its rival auction house Sotheby’s, and became its chief executive in February.

item.title: Harold Hamm, Oklahoma Oil Tycoon, Allies With Trump to Reshape U.S. Energy
item.description: Harold Hamm, an Oklahoma oil tycoon, has played a central role in reshaping energy policy by allying himself with President Trump.
item.dc:creator: Eric Lipton and Rebecca F. Elliott
item.media:credit: Loren Elliott for The New York Times

item.title: Fleece, Love and Vomit: New Yorkers’ Best (and Worst) SantaCon Stories
item.description: The bar crawl and charity fund-raiser has been eliciting strong reactions in the city for more than 25 years. Readers shared theirs.
item.dc:creator: Callie Holtermann

item.title: China Is Getting Much of What It Wants From the U.S., Including Chips
item.description: For China, President Trump’s moves to loosen chip controls, soften U.S. rhetoric and stay silent on tensions with Japan amount to a rare string of strategic gains.
item.dc:creator: Lily Kuo
item.media:description: President Trump and Xi Jinping, China’s leader, after their meeting in Busan, South Korea, in October. Mr. Trump’s latest moves extended the conciliatory posture he struck at this summit.
